It‚Äôs not the first time it‚Äôs happened, and it will not be the last. In many places here in Montana, it‚Äôs advised not to sleep in a tent because of the bears. Individuals need to use some common sense, we are currently drought out so natural food sources are practically nonexistent. You should always eat away from your tent and store your food away from your tent. You should always have bear spay or preferably a large firearm easily accessible at all times when in bear country and practice vigilance.

Rogue bears are rare but they do exist.  Four things to remember in bear country:
Keep food safely stored away from sleeping area, wash food off of hands and face. Never keep a morsel of food in your tent.  
Eat your meals at least 50 to 100 yards away from your sleeping area.  
For women - Best to stay out of bear country while menstruating (bears can smell blood up to 15 miles away). 
Never wear fragrant deodorant or perfume while hiking or backpacking

people need to be realistic out there with these animal protection rules...  I had my family on a 10 day guided pack string trip outside of Yellowstone a few years ago...  the guide had told me it was fine if I brought my own firearms, as he had them, as well...  when we were camping one night he asked me what kind of ammunition I had and told him high powered bear slugs designed for the purpose...  he was shocked, he told me I would kill the bear with it, that he used 00 buckshot and it would just part the hair and run off...   apparently the wild life commissions out there tag all of the bears with telemetry and can tell when a bear dies and the location through gps signal, so they can investigate..  he went on to tell me that unless there was evidence that the bear had harmed you that you would be prosecuted and he would lose his guide license...  to which, I had to tell him that if a bear was attacking my family, it was going to die no matter what...   that was Wyoming outside of Cody in the mountains..

I was riding with her on the Great Divide Trail that passes through Ovando. Leah was my best friend and she lived in northern Idaho for many years before  moving to California for a job.  I'm a Montana native but have also lived and worked in California. I now live in Eureka,  Montana near the boarder. During our trip from the  Canadian boarder to Ovando we camped in  different settings from campgrounds to wilderness  camps  and Leah was very bear aware. One night, in  a  wilderness camp,  she  and her sister, cooked well away  from  their tent and then hung their food about 3 hundred feet away. Other nights, in campgrounds, we used food storage boxes that are provided in some campgrounds. She didn't have any food in her  tent the night she died. Know, that  she was out doing what she loved and that she was a loving person, a friend, a daughter, a  sister and a nurse,  who at one time may have helped  someone you love. The community of Ovando is  devastated at  this time  but on the morning of the bear attack all I saw there was love and compassion for  myself, Leah's sister and all who  were  present. So, have some compassion and let us mourn for the loss of our  friend.
I hope she makes a full and speedy recovery.

Back when people still carried clubs and lived in caves, I was the T.A. for a university philosophy class, and I had the task of grading student papers.  One short paper assignment required students to assess the National Forest service policy of destroying bears that are known maulers.  My favorite answer:

"I think it is wrong because it has not been proved that destroying bears who maul people deters other bears from doing the same."

So this student was evidently imagining a sort of Far Side scenario featuring talking bears:  "If you're thinking of mauling that hiker, it ain't worth it, Henry.  Didn't you hear what they did to Frank?"
